headline.main: DNA and Insurance, Fate and Risk

docs.abstract: Should insurers be barred from seeing genetic tests for life, disability and long-term care coverage, so people can be tested without fear that the results would be used against them?
docs.snippet: Should insurers be barred from seeing genetic tests for life, disability and long-term care coverage, so people can be tested without fear that the results would be used against them?

docs.lead_paragraph: We need the equivalent of the EpiPen for snakebite.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Dr Matthew Lewin warns of danger annual monsoons in India pose due to venomous snakes seeking dry ground; contends that public health organizations pay surprisingly little attention to scourge of snake bites, which account for 94,000 deaths per year around the globe; maintains much more needs to be done.
docs.snippet: We need the equivalent of the EpiPen for snakebite.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Hillary Rodham Clinton contemplates another run for the presidency, few topics receive more scrutiny than her health, turning tabloid attention to the doctor who advises her and the former president.

headline.seo: Dr. Mark Hyman: Advising the Clintons on Their Health
headline.main: He Tells the Clintons How to Lose a Little
headline.print_headline: He Tells the Clintons How to Lose

docs.abstract: Tabloid attention has turned to diet and nutrition expert Dr Mark Hyman, adviser to Bill and Hillary Clinton, as Hillary contemplates second run for presidency and her health comes under scrutiny.
docs.snippet: As Hillary Rodham Clinton contemplates another run for the presidency, few topics receive more scrutiny than her health, turning tabloid attention to the doctor who advises her and the former president.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ophthalmologists say treatments like cataract operations and an expensive macular degeneration drug skew their Medicare reimbursements.

headline.main: Eye Doctors Say Their Profits Are Smaller Than Data Makes Them Look
headline.print_headline: Eye Doctors Say Their Profits Are Smaller Than They Look

docs.abstract: Newly released data reveals that ophthalmologists were the biggest recipients of Medicare money in 2012; reasons say volumes about an aging population and specialty that does many procedures, all well-reimbursed by Medicare; findings also reveal the difficulty of interpreting the Medicare data; ophthalmologists say their high representation among the list of big recipients is misleading, since bulk of Medicare money goes to costs of drugs they administer.
docs.snippet: Ophthalmologists say treatments like cataract operations and an expensive macular degeneration drug skew their Medicare reimbursements.

byline.original: By ANDREW POLLACK and REED ABELSON

docs.lead_paragraph: Although Iraq has only one confirmed case, the World Health Organization said dozens could be afflicted, primarily under-inoculated young children.

headline.main: Polio Spreads From Syria to Iraq, Causing Worries
headline.print_headline: Polio Spreads From Syria to Iraq, Causing Worries

docs.abstract: Syria's polio outbreak has officially spread to Iraq, first neighbor of war-ravaged country to be hit by the crippling virus despite an ambitious Middle East inoculation effort; global health officials warn that dozens of vulnerable Iraqi children could potentially be infected.
docs.snippet: Although Iraq has only one confirmed case, the World Health Organization said dozens could be afflicted, primarily under-inoculated young children.
